I'm trying to solve a simple exercise from early in the Theorem Proving with Lean 4 reference manual, but it's giving me a lot of trouble.

The problem is to show that 

p ∨ False ↔ p

which is clearly true, but I'm having difficulty showing it given the information provided thus far in the Theorem Proving reference. Particularly, I don't understand how to handle the False side of the OR statement. Intuitively, I want to say "False is never true, so this case doesn't matter".

Does anybody know what properties of False can be used to "ignore" this case in the Or.elim, or if there is something else that I should be doing instead?

Cheers!
The way to handle False is using docs#False.elim, which says that False implies everything
Oh, I see how that works. Sorry! I was trying to input arguments, which is why it didn't work. Thank you!
Maxwell Dodson has marked this topic as resolved.
